data.title: Rasheed Wallace chooses relevance
authors: Jim Fenton'Gatehouse News Service, MetroWest Daily News
data.meta_description: Rasheed Wallace will sign for the mid-level salary exception, which will be worth about $5.8 million, later this week and will add much-needed frontcourt depth to the Celtics.
data.text:
The Boston Celtics could not offer him a starting job or anything but the mid-level salary exception of less than $6 million.

What Rasheed Wallace could obtain from the Celtics was a chance to contend for another championship in the waning days of his NBA career.

Wallace, a free agent who turns 35 in September, agreed to a two-year contract on Sunday to become the centerpiece of the Celtics' bench.

The deal will be signed on Wednesday when free agents can finalize agreements and will be for the mid-level exception, which is expected to be about $5.8 million annually.

Wallace will serve as a backup to forward Kevin Garnett and center Kendrick Perkins after being a starter the majority of his career, which began in 1995 with the Washington Bullets.

Other contenders, such as the San Antonio Spurs and Orlando Magic, were said to be interested in Wallace, but he settled on the Celtics five days into the free-agent process.

The Celtics, who lacked depth in the frontcourt last season, sent Garnett, Ray Allen, Paul Pierce, Coach Doc Rivers, executive director of basketball operations Danny Ainge and owner Wyc Grousbeck to Wallace's house in Michigan last Thursday.

The group met with Wallace, his wife, and his agent, Bill Strickland, for three hours. That personal touch displayed by the Celtics helped direct Wallace, who won a title with the Detroit Pistons, to Boston.

After making $13.9 million in his final year with the Pistons, Wallace will be playing at a reduced salary and in a new role. Wallace, who has averaged 15 points and 6.9 rebounds in his career, has started all but 67 of his 1,009 regular-season games.

Wallace has been a controversial figure throughout his career, piling up technical fouls and drawing numerous fines from the NBA.

He fills a glaring need for the Celtics, giving them size up front, and Wallace is an accurate long-range shooter who can help Boston's defense as well.

When Garnett and Leon Powe were sidelined with injuries this past spring, Rivers turned to Brian Scalabrine as his first big man off the bench with the ineffective Mikki Moore behind him.

The addition of Wallace changes the look of the Celtics' bench, giving them a reliable sixth man, just like they had in the 2007-08 championship season with James Posey.

The acquisition of Wallace comes during an already hectic offseason for contenders in which the Magic traded for Vince Carter, the Cleveland Cavaliers dealt for Shaquille O'Neal, the Los Angeles Lakers picked up Ron Artest and the Spurs landed Richard Jefferson.

The Celtics' management team, which is in Florida for today's start of the Orlando Summer League, would like to further bolster the bench.

There have been reports that the Celtics have Grant Hill in their sights, hoping to give them a veteran wing player to spell Pierce. Hill played for Rivers in Orlando, where both currently reside.

The Celtics are also hoping to keep restricted free agent Glen Davis, who is being courted by several teams. Boston can match any offer Davis receives, though it is unlikely the Celtics will pay him $5 million per season.

(Jim Fenton writes for the Brockton Enterprise of Gatehouse News Service.)
